questions.question:
Which of the following predicate logic formulae/formula is/are CORRECT representation(s) of the statement: "Everyone has exactly one mother"?

The meanings of the predicates used are:
\(mother(y,x): y\) is the mother of \( x \)
\(noteq(x,y): x\) and \( y \) are not equal

(GATE CSE 2025 SET-1)
options:
A.

\( \forall x \exists y \exists z (mother(y, x) \land \neg mother(z, x)) \)

B.

\( \forall x \exists y [mother(y, x) \land \forall z (noteq(z, y) \to \neg mother(z, x))] \)

C.

\( \forall x \forall y [mother(y, x) \to \exists z (mother(z, x) \land \neg noteq(z, y))] \)

D.

\( \forall x \exists y [mother(y, x) \land \neg \exists z (noteq(z, y) \land mother(z, x))] \)
correct_answer:
B.

\( \forall x \exists y [mother(y, x) \land \forall z (noteq(z, y) \to \neg mother(z, x))] \)

D.

\( \forall x \exists y [mother(y, x) \land \neg \exists z (noteq(z, y) \land mother(z, x))] \)
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Let p and q be two propositions. Consider the following two formulae in propositional logic.

\(S1: (\neg p\wedge(p\vee q))\rightarrow q\)
\(S2: q\rightarrow(\neg p\wedge(p\vee q))\)

Which one of the following choices is correct?

(GATE CSE 2021 SET-1)
options:
B.

S1 is a tautology but S2 is not a tautology

C.

S1 is not a tautology but S2 is a tautology

D.

Niether S1 nor S2 is a tautology
questions.correct_answer:
B.

S1 is a tautology but S2 is not a tautology

questions.question:
Consider the first-order logic sentence
\(\varphi \equiv \exists s\exists t\exists u\forall v\forall w\forall x\forall y\varphi (s,t,u,v,w,x,y)\)
where \(\varphi (s,t,u,v,w,x,y)\) is a quantifier-free first-order logic formula using only predicate symbols, and possibly equality, but no function symbols. Suppose \(\varphi \) has a model with a universe containing 7 elements. Which one of the following statements is necessarily true?

(GATE CSE 2018)
options:
A.

There exists at least one model of \(\varphi\) with universe of size less than or equal to 3.

B.

There exists no model of \(\varphi\) with universe of size less than or equal to 3.

C.

There exists no model of \(\varphi\) with universe of size greater than 7.

D.

Every model of \(\varphi\) has a universe of size equal to 7.
questions.correct_answer:
A.

There exists at least one model of \(\varphi\) with universe of size less than or equal to 3.

questions.question:
Which one of the following well formed formulae is a tautology?

(GATE CSE 2015 SET-2)
options:
B.

\((\forall x[\exists yR(x,y)\rightarrow S(x,y)])\rightarrow \forall x\exists y S(x,y)\)

C.

\([\forall x\exists yP(x,y)\rightarrow R(x,y)]\leftrightarrow [\forall x\exists y(\neg P(x,y))\vee R(x,y)]\)

D.

\(\forall x \forall y P(x,y) \rightarrow \forall x\forall y P(y,x)\)
questions.correct_answer:
C.

\([\forall x\exists yP(x,y)\rightarrow R(x,y)]\leftrightarrow [\forall x\exists y(\neg P(x,y))\vee R(x,y)]\)

questions.question:
Let a(x, y), b(x, y,) and c(x, y) be three statements with variables x and y chosen from some universe. Consider the following statement:
\(\qquad(\exists x)(\forall y)[(a(x, y) \wedge b(x, y)) \wedge \neg c(x, y)]\)
Which one of the following is its equivalent?

(GATE IT 2004)
options:
A.

\((\forall x)(\exists y)[(a(x, y) \vee b(x, y)) \to c(x, y)]\)

B.

\((\exists x)(\forall y)[(a(x, y) \vee b(x, y)) \wedge\neg c(x, y)]\)

C.

\(\neg (\forall x)(\exists y)[(a(x, y) \wedge b(x, y)) \to c(x, y)]\)

D.

\(\neg (\forall x)(\exists y)[(a(x, y) \vee b(x, y)) \to c(x, y)]\)
questions.correct_answer:
C.

\(\neg (\forall x)(\exists y)[(a(x, y) \wedge b(x, y)) \to c(x, y)]\)

B.

C.

D.

B.
